docs.snippet: Mark Sanchez, the former starting quarterback for the Jets, will compete to be the backup to Nick Foles, a position filled last season by Michael Vick, now of the Jets....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Sanchez, the former starting quarterback for the Jets, will compete to be the backup to Nick Foles, a position filled last season by Michael Vick, now of the Jets.
docs.abstract: Mark Sanchez, the former starting quarterback for the New York Jets, will compete to be the backup to Philadelphia Eagles' Nick Foles, a position filled last season by Michael Vick, now of the Jets.

headline.main: Completing a Circle, the Eagles Sign Sanchez to Replace Vick
headline.print_headline: Completing a Circle, the Eagles Sign Sanchez to Replace Vick

docs.snippet: If Northwestern and other universities don’t want to deal with unions for athletes, they should stop fighting their players and work with them to improve conditions....
docs.lead_paragraph: If Northwestern and other universities don’t want to deal with unions for athletes, they should stop fighting their players and work with them to improve conditions.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends football players at colleges like Northwestern University devote more time to football than many full-time employees devote to their jobs; welcomes ruling by National Labor Relations Board that Northwestern players are eligible to form a union.

headline.main: Playing College Football Is a Job
headline.print_headline: Playing College Football Is a Job

docs.snippet: Northwestern University said April 9 is the deadline for it to file an appeal opposing a U.S. National Labor Relations Board decision that declared Northwestern football players to be school employees and allowed them to hold a union election vote...
docs.lead_paragraph: Northwestern University said April 9 is the deadline for it to file an appeal opposing a U.S. National Labor Relations Board decision that declared Northwestern football players to be school employees and allowed them to hold a union election vote.

headline.main: Northwestern Says Its Views on Football Players Union 'Overlooked'
headline.print_headline: Northwestern Says Its Views on Football Players Union 'Overlooked'

docs.snippet: A ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize has highlighted the growing battle over how much college players should share in the billions of dollars they generate....
docs.lead_paragraph: A ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize has highlighted the growing battle over how much college players should share in the billions of dollars they generate.
docs.abstract: Ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize highlights growing battle over how much college players should share in billions of dollars they generate for their schools and National Collegiate Athletic Association; college athletics, however, hardly resemble free market and, unlike private enterprises, sports departments at big schools do not have to be profitable in any strict sense.

headline.main: College Athletes Aim to Put Price on ‘Priceless’
headline.print_headline: College Athletes Aim to Put Price on ‘Priceless’

byline.original: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ and STEVE EDER

docs.snippet: A ruling that Northwestern football players had won the right to be considered university employees is not only about money, some college basketball players said....
docs.lead_paragraph: A ruling that Northwestern football players had won the right to be considered university employees is not only about money, some college basketball players said.
docs.abstract: Juliet Macur Sports of The Times column; ruling that Northwestern football players have won the right to be considered university employees could forever change the landscape of college sports; ruling, if upheld, would allow players to form a union, to win more rights and protections--perhaps even paychecks--in return for their contributions to the business of college sports; NCAA is likely to fight ruling if it is not overturned.

headline.main: For College Players, Gaining Rights Amid Guarded Words
